title: "Notion is my creative command center a must-have for designers"
description: What I love most about Notion is how customizable and flexible it is. I’ve built personalized dashboards for each client, organized all my design files, and even created moodboards right inside Notion. The ability to switch between kanban, calendar, and list views makes managing design workflows a breeze. Sharing pages with clients and getting real-time feedback saves a lot of time and keeps everything organized. Sometimes, the mobile experience isn't as smooth as the desktop version, especially when working with image-heavy pages. It also lacks deep integrations with key design tools like Figma or Adobe Creative Cloud, which would make it even more powerful for creatives like me. And while the app is super flexible, beginners might feel overwhelmed with the blank canvas at first. Notion helped me bring all my design work, client tasks, and creative ideas into one place, making everything easier to manage and much more organized.

title: "All-in-One Productivity Tool for Work and Personal Use"
description: I really appreciate how versatile Notion is having docs, tasks, and databases all in one place. The clean UI, customizable templates, and ability to link pages make it perfect for both structured planning and creative brainstorming.  Notion works great for managing both personal and team projects. During my Product Fellowship, we used it to structure our entire product workflow from ideation and roadmaps to documentation and feedback tracking. The real-time collaboration and ability to customize boards, tables, and checklists made everything smoother and more transparent. The mobile version can lag, especially when navigating large or complex pages. Offline access is also limited, which can be inconvenient when working on the go or in low-connectivity areas.  It can feel a bit overwhelming for first-time users, especially when building more advanced workflows or databases. Some features like integrations with other tools or timeline views could also be improved for better scalability. Notion helps centralize all my work—documents, tasks, and product workflows into one organized space. During my Product Fellowship, it enabled smooth collaboration, clear ownership, and easy tracking of roadmaps, meeting notes, and feedback.  It solved problems like scattered communication, lack of documentation, and unclear task management. This has greatly improved team alignment, transparency, and productivity.
reviewerTitle: Transitioning from Software developer to Product management

title: "Notion is the Perfect Tool to Catalyst your Productivity"
description: What I like most about Notion is there is value no matter how much you know about it. Just starting out, it can easily be used as a note application, just as good as Evernote or Mem, but with massive room to customize your interface as you would like. As you learn about databases, relationships, and the slew of 3rd party integrations, you have infinite directions you could take it. I use Notion as my planner, notes, contact list, project manager, resource manager, goal tracker, storyboard, travel planner, and any other idea I may have, like organizing my writing or tracking my inventory and orders through my multiple different side hustles. Along with the reliable Notion AI, providing different options directly in the workspace and in the chat box, with syncing between any number of pages, I can magnify the rate at which I work and brainstorm. Not many of my friends use Notion like they should, but if they did, I can use Notion workspaces to collaborate with them at the same level! Notion has as much potential as you do and will only reach that potential if you put some time into making it yours.  And in a fitting testament to Notion's capabilities, this review was [PROOFREAD!]  by the very AI it praises, showcasing the seamless integration of human creativity and artificial intelligence. Notion has not touched this text. As a platform for optimizing my productivity, it is perfect. What I find difficult is understanding how I can best use it, from the very beginning. I think many people will try the application, hearing how useful it is, but be disappointed when they first try it and think it's just another notes app. Of course it is a good one, but people may have large collection of notes, and likely won't want to spend the time copying those notes over if they don't know why Notion is worth it. Only when I did the research into Notion on my own, did I realize it's capabilities, and I had downloaded it months prior. I actually didn't even use Notion at all and came back to it later when my friend insisted that it would be worth it.  All I am saying is a little bit of a tutorial at the beginning, embedded in the first launch of the program, could not only display how to use the app right, but give the launch of the program a professional air. Notion isn't just another notes app, it's going to change your life, and it deserves your attention from the start. Notion is fixing my cohesion within my life. I have always hated how everything that I use to get through the day is in separate application that I need to have access to simultaneously. With Notion I consolidate my life into one place, so I can see the puzzle I am building with all the pieces in front of me, instead of having to remember which spot I left each one. Imagine playing a videogame and not have a UI with your health, ammo, mini map, or goal trackers. You can probably figure it out or "look" in at your belt to know how many grenades you have left. But with the UI, you know without having to even look away from the path ahead.

title: "Disappointed"
description: I was drawn to the wide range of possibilities the software offers. You can use it for any type of project—personal notes, tracking, or even large-scale tasks. And of course integrations. I usually enjoy setting up project management tools, but this time I found it challenging. The UX is not easy to get. Content blocks are not sync. For instance, I couldn't find out how to have the same calendar view in every page, even when I connected the calendar to my gmail account. I can't customise background colors, setting up a good layout is impossible...but the most important, I can't find out how to track task with the team. Implementation is not that easy as it promised. Furthemore, templates are not that great. I tried to find Youtube tutorials and some knowledge from experts, but I couldn't find anything interesting. Notion meants to track marketing initiatives and campaigns. We need a system to have the team on the same page.

title: "It started simple, now it is an ecosystem"
description: Notion started as a block-based text editor with some DB functionality. I have been using it from the very start, when you found one or two videos about the "new cool app". A lot of the hacky solutions we did back then have been implemented, so they for sure listen for feedback. It has been easy to implement, and with the API, we get data from it. It is also easy to share and use. I use it personally all the time, and the company i work for has documentation on it. The rapid change-pace makes some solutions stop working because they simplified a changed something down the line. Has happen once or twice but it was me breaking it a biiiit before. Also, the formula editor is disgusting to use to be honest. It is a knowledge base for the company. I use it to do note taking and report on my tasks to my manager. I have helped a co-worker set up a Notion form to get design work done on their end.

title: "My favorite app"
description: Notion is incredibly flexible and lets me organize my work and personal life in one place. I love how I can build custom pages, databases, and keep everything from meeting notes to project plans easily accessible. It’s super helpful for staying organized without being tied to a rigid structure. It really adapts to how you think and work. It's very powerful but there's a learning curve to reach out the max potential of it. Notion helps me centralize all my work in one place. I use it to manage projects, keep track of client work, document processes, and even plan content calendars. It’s especially useful for collaborating with remote teams since everything is accessible, editable, and organized. It’s helped me work more efficiently and stay on top of tasks without needing a bunch of separate tools.

title: "Notion Review"
description: Notion is one of the most versatile productivity tools I’ve ever used. It combines notes, docs, databases, wikis, calendars, project boards, and task lists into one clean, unified interface. You’re not locked into rigid templates—the flexibility is incredible.  I love how:  Everything is drag-and-drop and highly customizable.  It supports Markdown, slash commands, and real-time collaboration.  The database views (Kanban, table, gallery, calendar) make it easy to track projects or build internal tools.  It replaces a stack of tools (Google Docs, Trello, Evernote, Confluence, Airtable) with just one.  Plus, the design is minimal and intuitive, which makes it a joy to use daily. While I love Notion, it’s not perfect:  Offline access is limited—you need a consistent internet connection for full functionality.  For large teams or complex workflows, performance can lag (especially with very large databases or lots of embedded media).  It lacks robust permissions granularity compared to enterprise tools like Confluence or SharePoint.  There’s a learning curve for non-technical users who aren’t used to building systems from scratch. Scattered Information & Tool Overload Problem: We used to rely on multiple disconnected tools—Google Docs for notes, Trello for tasks, Evernote for personal stuff, Confluence for wikis. It was chaotic, and information was hard to find or maintain.  How Notion Solves It: Notion centralizes everything in one place: documents, databases, wikis, project boards, and notes—all easily linked together.  Benefit:  Reduces context switching between tools.  Saves time by having a single source of truth for everything.  Easier onboarding for new team members with centralized documentation.

title: "The Dream Teammate for Entrepreneurs!"
description: Notion AI, especially the new meeting notes feature is a game changer for anyone venturing out on their own. It's like having an assistant or coordinator to sit alongside you in meetings to capture all the important details and action items while you are giving your full attention to the meeting attendees. I cannot express enough how much this has helped me and my productivity!! I also love that I can ask Notion AI questions as I'm setting up new workflows and pages if I don't know how to achieve my goals. I am excited for Notion AI to get smarter. I want to reach vibe code levels where I can explain what I want a workflow to do and it can go ahead and build it for me and link to other databases. I also wish that the action items in the meeting notes could auto populate into my to-do list and help connect the dots to other items in the project. Organizes my entire business in one place. As an entrepreneur working remote on every project and often on the road traveling, I love having all my notes and details for all my projects accessible and no longer on scratch pieces of paper that I inevitably lose in the shuffle of travel. My next goal is to be able to funnel important pieces of this info into client portals so clients are seeing the same real time data I am for better collaboration and success!

title: "A flexible, all-in-one workspace that adapts to any workflow"
description: Notion makes it incredibly easy to organize information, collaborate with teammates, and build custom workflows without writing code. I love how flexible it is,  I use it everyday for everything from product specs and meeting notes to project tracking and team dashboards. The ability to create linked databases and toggle views makes managing even complex documentation feel effortless. It was super easy to implement and integrate into our company's workflows. We haven't had any customer support interactions, but I imagine they would be flawless. Sometimes performance can lag when working in large databases or pages with a lot of embedded content. There’s also a learning curve for new users, especially those unfamiliar with Notion’s flexibility,  it can feel overwhelming at first. But all things I can live with. I love Notion!!! Notion is incredibly helpful for writing product proposals, organizing research, and quickly finding information across our knowledge base. It allows our team to collaborate in real time and link context across docs, tasks, and data sources,  all in one place. The ability to embed data, tag content, and build structured documentation makes it perfect for managing cross-functional work.

title: "Endless possibilities, though a bit of a learning curve"
description: Notion’s versatility is truly impressive. Its ability to adapt to virtually any workflow makes it a powerful tool for organizing information, managing projects, and building custom systems. Notion AI is a standout feature, bringing an extra layer of intelligence and efficiency to content creation and task management. The creative possibilities with this platform feel almost limitless. There is a learning curve, especially for new users. At first, the interface and depth of features can feel overwhelming, and it takes some time to fully unlock its potential. Notion is solving multiple challenges by acting as an all-in-one workspace. It streamlines project management, combines a powerful AI-enhanced text editor, and serves as a centralized database and operations hub for my agency. Instead of juggling multiple tools, I can manage everything—from strategic planning to task tracking and documentation—in a single, flexible platform. This integration has boosted my team’s productivity, improved collaboration, and given us a clearer overview of our priorities and progress.

title: "One of the best knowledge and productivity tools available."
description: I use notion every day in both my personal and professional lives.  I like that way that AI tools are implemented to focus on what AI is good at doing and not replacing human creativity.  Integrations make it easy to be a knowledge hub to organize information flow between systems while maintaining a source of truth.  It's easy enough to implement, and very easy to onboard collaborators with very little training. I wish it had more built in visualization tools like mind mapping and graphs. There are 3rd party tools, but they are far from seamless.  There is a little learning curve getting your projects set up initially and it can very easily become a chaotic mess  (that's more on me than an actual issue with Notion) Documenting calls and meetings, tracking action items,  knowledge base, project management.  It keeps projects documented and up to date, keeps everyone informed and collaborators organized.

title: "Versatile All-in-One Workspace That Scales"
description: I love Notion’s block-based pages and database system—being able to turn any page into a table, board, calendar, or gallery instantly is incredibly powerful. The vast library of community-created templates means I can get started on anything from meeting notes to product roadmaps in seconds. Its real-time collaboration features let me work with teammates seamlessly, and the sleek, distraction-free interface keeps me focused on what matters most. Notion can become sluggish on very large or media-heavy pages, and its offline support is still somewhat limited—editing without an internet connection sometimes leads to sync conflicts. The learning curve for advanced database relations and rollups is steeper than it appears, so power-user features can feel intimidating at first. Customer support response times can vary, and some native automation and reminder capabilities still lag behind dedicated task managers. Notion solves the “too many disconnected tools” problem by unifying notes, docs, task boards, and databases in one flexible workspace—no more juggling separate apps for writing, spreadsheets, kanban, or knowledge bases. For me, that means:  Single source of truth: All project specs, meeting notes, and research live in one place, so I never waste time hunting through emails or shared drives.  Custom workflows instead of rigid templates: I can build exactly the structure I need—whether it’s a CRM-style database, an editorial calendar, or a personal journal—and tweak it on the fly as requirements evolve.  Real-time collaboration without context switching: Team members can comment, assign tasks, and update status directly in the doc or board we’re already using, cutting down on Slack pings and duplicate status meetings.  Automated roll-ups and dashboards: By linking task databases to higher-level roadmaps, I get a live overview of progress without manually copying updates.  Altogether, these capabilities have cut my tool-hopping in half, accelerated onboarding for new teammates, and kept everyone aligned on priorities—so our projects move faster and with fewer miscommunications.

title: "Notion AI - not the ordinary AI!"
description: Notion AI has transformed how our Sales team finds, summarizes, and leverages content. What used to take hours—like digging through 300-slide decks or multiple repositories—is now done in minutes. Its ability to search across both Notion and Google Drive (without uploading anything manually!) is a superpower for our company. It’s incredibly intuitive and accurate, and has become a go-to for everything from RFI responses to demo prep. We’d love deeper integrations-especially with Gong. While there's a potential workaround via API, a native one-click connection would be ideal. Our Sales team struggled with two major pain points:  Finding and summarising information fast  Accessing content stored outside Notion (especially on Google Drive)  Notion AI solved both. It’s particularly useful for finding specific slides or content pieces, generating RFI responses (better than tools like Hypercomply), and even searching through legal docs and order forms. It’s saving our AEs roughly 1 hour/week each, and scaling that across the GTM team gives us a serious productivity lift.

title: "Some UI issues, but generally a great experience."
description: Ease of formatting (especially toggle sections and coloring), notion AI in the main app is quite helpful, sharing is easy and synced blocks are also an awesome feature Sometimes the UI in the mac app behaves really weird, e.g. it won't show the 6 dots on the left of a block to drag it. On an iPad without a keyboard, rearranging blocks is almost impossible. Sometimes it will allow me to edit one part of the page but not the other. It it is because of access settings, it would be great to have a more clear indication in the UI. Also, Notion main seems really unfinished, it kept completely freezing on my Mac so can't use it right now. Additionally, it won't allow me to add a logo/picture to my default signature, even though the same one works fine on gmail/outlook. Helps build guides for employees for internal processes. For project management we also try using tables/timelines in notion, but it seems overly complicated and not very intuitive to use

title: "It optimizes information sharing within the team."
description: The ability to easily share data. Members are automatically notified when data is added or modified, which helps optimize communication. New features are being added one after another, and it’s becoming possible to build entire systems using Notion alone. Although we haven’t fully leveraged the generative AI features yet, we expect them to contribute significantly to improving our operational efficiency in the future. The user interface seems to be quite difficult for older generations to understand. Also, it can be inconvenient to use without a touchscreen. In addition, I would like to see more flexibility in designing the screen layout. I have implemented many of our internal business workflows in Notion, incorporating features such as information sharing, preventing task omissions, and obtaining manager approvals. This has helped solve a number of operational issues. Since the implementation can be easily modified, we are also able to improve functions at a rapid pace.

title: "Amazing job at taking Meeting notes"
description: I love notion in general, but now with integrated AI its next level compared to any note taking app. I think the fact that it is able to summarize my meeting and I can send minutes out right after with Action items is a game changer. I told my boss about it right away and he wants to get it as well. I just started using the AI meeting feature but have been using notion AI for a while to organize my notes and its mostly been great. When I had notion organize one of my pages, it made hyperlinks to things and I liked the way it was organized but the hyperlinks don't work. I've tried multiple times. So I would almost have to manually copy what it suggests to make it work. Which is frustrating and I just wouldn't bother. making me able to organize my various meetings. Being able to search my notes to find what I need. Consolidating all my information and using that to get me answers. the AI note taker during meetings is a game changer.
reviewerTitle: I own a rental property company with my husband. Co-Owner.

title: "My Dashboard for Everything"
description: I've been using Notion to some extent for several years, but it's recently become my dashboard for nearly everything I do. With notion I can easily set up tools, tasks, and trackers for just about anything I need to keep up with, and it's all in one place where I can find it easily.  I've recently moved over to Notion email and have already gotten a more manageable inbox with just a bit of configuration. I've also moved a lot of my writing over from Google Docs to notion since the inline AI tool allows me to use AI to do research and get pointers without having to go to an outside app or page. I've had some problems with running notion as an autostart program. It loads, but doesn't work and I have to close and restart it. Otherwise the only issue I've seen was a calendar problem that turned out to be because I hadn't updated. It's helping me get organized so I always have a prioritized list of things I need to do, ideas I want to develop, and projects I need to work on. I've also incorporated into my workflow for writing and for scheduling blog posts.

title: "Love Notion and the functionality"
description: I love the databases with the views and filtering system the most. It's easy to keep track of similar and different types of information and group them depending on what tags etc you have set. It's very customizable for any sort of project or tracking system you want to create. You just have to figure out what you need from the data and how you want to view it. I don't use the AI or automation much on a personal preference. The AI doesn't have the capability to edit databases which is the only thing I would most likely use it for In my opinion, the app could use a lot of work: - would be nice to be able to use keyboard shortcuts like /heading etc in app as well - img inserting has errors. More than one usually causes reloading and having to reupload img - Capability to reposition photos in gallery view - Dragging properties / tags around has lag time / sometimes gets stuck in between lines and you need to refresh - Gallery view with smaller icons for app instead of one box column only option - Option to bold / text treatment within properties (ex. Can bold a text property on computer, but option doesn't appear on phone) - Being able to paste in images from phone / keyboard - More text / style /color options without having to code - being able to duplicate new sync blocks that aren't connected if you want to create multiple at a time - being able to delete all synced block data when disconnecting instead of just disconnecting and leaving info on each of pages - More icon options - Being able to hide the original un-deletable name property on front view - being able to drag properties shown / hidden order in settings of database (currently have to hide all the ones up to the position you want new property to be placed and then reselect other properties you hid back to view) - Overload of assets and information with no proper way to organize - management of other apps used and consolidation of access - training hubs & center for all employees to locate information that is synced - Verification tracker for updating old assets

title: "I think it's so much more visually appealing and has 10x functionality to google sheets"
description: I find that Notion stands out as a highly customizable and visually appealing workspace, offering a range of organizational tools that support both my personal workflow and our team’s productivity. I really appreciate its flexibility—it lets me structure pages in multiple ways, like using nested pages, tables, and kanban boards. It's easy to navigate, and I love being able to embed content from one page into another, which makes it ideal for building comprehensive, interconnected resources. The clean and intuitive interface also helps our team stay aligned without the clutter that comes with more traditional documentation tools. I’ve found that Notion does come with a bit of a learning curve, especially when it comes to more advanced features like relational databases. I've struggled with trying to connect entries across multiple databases or sheets, which can be frustrating when managing more complex workflows. The formatting can also be restrictive at times—I’ve run into issues with unexpected locks or trouble figuring out how to reformat things the way I want. While I appreciate how customizable Notion is, really mastering all of its features takes time and patience, which can be challenging when I'm looking for quick, straightforward solutions. For me, Notion serves as a powerful internal solution by acting as both a centralized knowledge base and a collaboration hub for our team. It helps me consolidate scattered information into one organized space where I can easily access documentation, project plans, meeting notes, and shared resources. I really value the real-time editing, the ability to embed content, and how seamlessly pages can link to one another—it’s been a huge help in breaking down silos and improving collaboration across teams. It ensures that important knowledge isn’t just stored, but is easy to find and stays up to date, which makes our workflows a lot more transparent and efficient.

title: "Notion helps me figure out my life"
description: • I love the organization of Notion and the sub-pages ability. • I love the existing type styling • The databases' properties that show up within an item's page is very useful • The collaborative of Notion is great in comparison to some other documentation tools • I dislike how hard it is to use databases: the items within databases cannot be moved to another database, once it's a full page database it's not intuitive to change it to an inline-database • Sometimes it Notion feels clunky (the UX interactions, e.g. moving 1 text chunk to a difference column) • I wish Notion had more styling capabilities (e.g. being able to add bullet points or images into tables, being able to adjust cell padding when I add another column) • I do not need AI in Notion, I find it quite upsetting and useless • I often need a centralized place to store information and Notion is my first choice, then GSuite (the share function's UX is a lot nicer than Google Docs) • Being able to upload PDFs, Figma links, preview various images is incredibly useful for meeting notes

title: "A fantastic tool for work, school, and home."
description: After using Notion for a couple of years now, I can confidently say it's been a game-changer for my academic work, research organization, and personal life. The platform's flexibility in creating interconnected pages and databases has revolutionized how I manage my projects and course materials.  The ability to embed content, link between pages, and create hierarchical structures makes it incredibly efficient for managing complex projects. I particularly appreciate how easy it is to transform loose notes into structured databases, and how seamlessly you can cross-reference information across different pages.  For academics and researchers, Notion's collaborative features are invaluable. You can easily share specific pages with colleagues or students while maintaining privacy for your other content. The platform's clean, minimalist interface reduces distractions while still offering powerful organizational tools when you need them. This past semester, I used notion exclusively for sharing course content, instructions, and tutorials with my students. The platform's export options, while adequate for basic needs, could be expanded to support more file formats and maintain better formatting fidelity. For academic work specifically, better integration with citation management tools and improved formatting options for academic writing would be valuable additions. I use Notion AI to quickly summarize academic journal articles, and to highlight the important information. The ability to quickly and easily generate work flow tutorials that can be shared with learners saves me time. The databasing abilities have made project management so much easier.

title: "Highlights & Drawbacks"
description: Notion’s greatest strength is its all-in-one flexibility: you can seamlessly mix notes, tasks, wikis, tables and boards in a single page without ever leaving the app. Its drag-and-drop block system makes building custom layouts intuitive, while relational databases let you link and roll up information across pages. Real-time collaboration and inline comments keep teams aligned and eliminate version-control headaches. With cross-platform sync and a rich template library, Notion adapts to virtually any workflow and helps you stay focused on what matters. While Notion is powerful, its abundance of features can feel overwhelming at first—new users may struggle to find where to start or how best to structure their workspace. Performance can lag on pages with heavy embeds or large databases, especially on mobile devices. Some advanced database functions (like formulas and rollups) have a steeper learning curve than in traditional spreadsheet tools. Finally, offline support is limited, so you’ll need a reliable connection to make the most of the app. Tool Sprawl & Context Switching → Notion unifies notes, tasks, wikis and databases in one workspace, so you spend less time hopping between apps and more time getting work done.  Knowledge Silos & Fragmented Docs → Its customizable pages and relational databases link information across projects, keeping everyone aligned and ensuring nothing falls through the cracks.

title: "How Notion Became My Essential Hub for Work, Creativity, and Team Collaboration"
description: I use Notion every single day. I appreciate the comprehensive knowledge it has about me, as I use it for journaling and personal knowledge management. When I ask Notion AI a question, it has all the necessary context to provide me with the answers I want, even if my description of my search is vague. It's hard to recommend to my friends because of the vast amount of ways you could use Notion considering that I am the type to tinker with my software and most people are not. Though the onboarding process has improved much in the last few years I've been using it.  I asked Notion AI to write me a review based on my workspace which has all my opinions from my meetings and journal entries and this is what it gave me (excluding links, of course):  Here’s my honest review of Notion, based on my experience onboarding colleagues, building workflows, and convincing teams to actually use it:  - Notion is truly the all-in-one workspace. I started using it for personal projects long before I pitched it to my company, and it’s been a game-changer for managing huge volumes of product photos and assets in a way that’s actually visual and intuitive—not just “another spreadsheet.”  - What I appreciate most: flexibility. Notion is basically the Lego of productivity tools—everything you build is made up of blocks, whether it’s databases, tables, notes, or galleries. That makes it easy to adapt for tasks as simple as a to-do list or as complex as multi-team project management.  - Its databases are a lifesaver. I’ve used Notion to track thousands of product samples and their distribution to vendors like Walmart and Amazon. Everything is searchable, filterable, and updatable—no more guessing what’s done and what isn’t.  - The team onboarding process has a learning curve, no question. Not everyone “gets” Notion right away, and I’ve seen that first-hand while training new hires and walking colleagues through image requests and workflow automations. But once people see how everything’s in one place and how they can interact with live data, adoption goes way up.  - Automations are another huge plus. I’m pretty big on workflow optimization, and Notion’s tools for automating repetitive tasks have streamlined a lot of the things I used to do manually—or worse, had to chase down teammates for.  - Downsides? Permissions and sharing can be fiddly, especially with large teams or when onboarding. The learning curve is real, and I’ve had to nudge quite a few people over the “just another tool” hump. But once the infrastructure is there, it pays off with real time savings and better collaboration.  - There’s a creative side too—I love being able to build custom trackers and dashboards for everything from e-commerce content to personal hobbies. I even showed a team member my drinks tasting database as an example of how anything you can imagine is possible in Notion!  Likes: Flexible and visual: Notion lets you organize projects, images, and information in a way that fits how you think and work. You appreciate being able to customize layouts, databases, and dashboards for both team workflows and personal projects.⁠ ⁠⁠ ⁠​ All-in-one workspace: You like that Notion combines notes, task management, and database features, so everything’s in one place—no getting lost between different apps.⁠ ⁠​ Powerful automations: Setting up automations and custom notifications saves you time and helps keep teams on track with status updates and reminders.⁠ ⁠​ Multiple views: You enjoy having options like board (Kanban), table, gallery, and calendar views to see data from different angles—much more versatile than tools like Trello.⁠ ⁠⁠ ⁠​ Collaboration: Real-time editing and sharing make it easy for team members to stay updated, track changes, and work together on shared projects.⁠  In short: Notion isn’t perfect, but if you’re willing to invest some time in setup and onboarding, it can totally transform how you (and your team) work, collaborate, and stay organized. For me, it’s indispensable—and I keep finding new ways to bend it to what I need next. Dislikes: Learning curve: Notion can be overwhelming for new users, especially during onboarding. Getting everyone comfortable and using it well takes time and patience.⁠ ⁠⁠ ⁠​ Permissions and sharing: Managing access and sharing with large teams can get fiddly, causing confusion at times.⁠ ⁠​ Bulk downloads: Downloading multiple files at once isn’t straightforward—you often have to grab files one at a time, which is inconvenient for image-heavy workflows.⁠ ⁠​ Occasional resistance: Teams or colleagues accustomed to other tools (like Excel or old workflows) may be slow to adopt Notion, even when it clearly works better.⁠ I created a product tracker in Notion and shared it with the company I work for. I also trained them how to use it. I also made some project management workflows in Notion that solve problems, such as generating style numbers for products and designs.

title: "A seamless support system"
description: The time from idea to MVP for almost anything you need is significantly shorter that with any other tool.  Getting the average user onboard is quick, and overall onboarding is quicker than ever with bundles of information, tools, resources all in one place.  Implementation of Notion itself is no simple feat, but it has lots of ways to migrate and import data, and while the AI aspects work better while being fed with data, small tools/guides/trackers/Knowledgebases can be created in silos to manage a progressive deployment.  Before long you will  findyourself living daily in notion. My largest daily struggle would have to be slow database times. There is a diminishing return on database size.  Additionally the gap in user levels. Notion is something where if you get it, you get it quick. If you struggle, you must have never played with Lego as a kid and might just not get it. If that's the case, the more capable users will need to manage access very carefully to prevent accidents. Unification!  Visibility for many people in the same place, and a shared repository of knowledge.

title: "A flexible and all-in-one tool for knowledge management and team collaboration."
description: What I value most about Notion is its flexibility to adapt to different workflows—whether it's complex databases or simple collaborative documents. Its ability to centralize tasks, notes, documentation, and project management in one place reduces information fragmentation and improves traceability. The intuitive interface and wide template ecosystem also make onboarding faster for cross-functional teams. I miss having more robust native integrations with key tools like Jira or business intelligence platforms. Notion is helping solve the fragmentation of information across teams and tools by centralizing documentation, project tracking, and internal communication in a single, customizable workspace. The built-in AI writing assistant accelerates content creation, from meeting summaries to structured documentation, saving time and reducing cognitive load. Its knowledge base capabilities allow for scalable documentation that’s easy to structure, maintain, and search—especially valuable in remote or asynchronous teams. The recent improvements in enterprise search make it significantly easier to surface relevant information across workspaces, reducing time wasted looking for documents or context. Altogether, Notion is improving operational efficiency and helping teams stay aligned.

title: "A Truly Versatile Powerhouse for Organising Work and Thinking Clearly"
description: Notion is, hands down, the most versatile tool I’ve ever used. It’s a true blank canvas that can adapt to whatever I need—project management, wikis, documentation, internal communication, or structured databases. It gives me one unified space to organise work, ideas, and teams without enforcing a rigid structure. The new AI features take it up another level: I can keep all my client notes, documents, and tickets in one place and then ask Notion to generate new content or answer questions with full context already loaded. It’s clean, focused, and free from unnecessary UI clutter like font options or locked-in workflows. It just gets out of the way and lets you think. The formula system in Notion is a bit of a learning curve—it doesn’t follow the same logic or syntax as Excel or Google Sheets, which can be frustrating at first if you’re used to those tools. Also, for new users, the sheer flexibility of Notion can feel overwhelming. It takes a bit of time and intentional setup to really unlock its potential. But once you’re past that, it’s incredibly powerful. Notion has solved the problem of scattered tools and siloed information. Instead of juggling separate apps for project management, note-taking, internal documentation, and client records, I now have everything in one place. This means less context-switching, better collaboration, and a much clearer overview of both the big picture and the granular details. The AI features are also saving me time by helping generate content, summarise discussions, and surface key insights—all within the same workspace that already holds the relevant information. It’s massively improved our team’s organisation, speed, and clarity.

title: "A Powerful All-in-One Workspace with Smart AI Support"
description: Notion makes it incredibly easy to stay organized across projects, notes, and tasks. The interface is clean and flexible, and the search function is fast and reliable—even across large amounts of content. Notion AI has been a game changer for me; it’s especially helpful for generating summaries and saving time on content review. There is a bit of a learning curve when getting started. While it’s generally intuitive, some features and workflows take a bit of time to fully grasp, especially if you’re not used to modular, drag-and-drop style tools. Notion helps manage and organize large amounts of information in a way that’s both structured and flexible. It serves as a centralized knowledge base for our organization, making it easy to document, access, and maintain everything from processes to project updates. The search functionality is excellent—much faster and more accurate than what we’ve experienced with tools like Google Drive. Overall, it reduces friction in finding and sharing information, which has improved team efficiency and transparency.

title: "The most flexible and powerful productivity platform I’ve used."
description: What I love most about Notion is its incredible versatility—whether I need to keep things simple with a clean task list or build a complex database system for a client, Notion handles it all. The built-in AI assistant has become an essential part of my workflow, helping me brainstorm, summarize, and draft content quickly across both personal projects and client deliverables. I onboard every new client onto Notion, and the process is always smooth. They find it intuitive and enjoy the ability to collaborate in real-time with all documentation and processes centralized in one place. While I appreciate the vast capabilities, the flexibility can be a double-edged sword—new users can sometimes feel overwhelmed by the open-ended nature of the platform without guidance or templates. I would love for there to be an offline mode - enabling me to edit . Lastly, I’d love to see even deeper integrations with external tools like Google Drive, Slack, and QuickBooks without needing workarounds or third-party automation tools. Notion is solving a major problem I’ve faced for years—scattered tools and fragmented information. Instead of jumping between separate apps for project management, documentation, note-taking, CRM, and content planning, I now manage everything within a single, unified workspace. This has significantly improved my operational efficiency, reduced context-switching, and helped me stay organized both personally and professionally. For my clients, it streamlines onboarding, centralizes SOPs and assets, and enables transparent collaboration. The ability to customize every workspace to match the client’s needs—whether for marketing, operations, or creative workflows—adds tremendous value. The AI tools enhance this further by saving time on writing, summarizing meetings, and creating content drafts, allowing me to focus more on high-impact work.

title: "It was the best of apps, it was the worst of apps: why Notion is the blorst"
description: Notion should be thought of as a "no-code IDE" and from this frame, it is unmatched. I don't know of any other app that gives you databases and markdown to play with in such a freestyle way. For applications like building a "life OS" or bespoke project management dashboard, Notion's flexibility and framework agnosticism are appealing. I've used Notion to run almost every aspect of my life for several years, it's excellent for my (very specific) needs. Honestly it has changed my life. Notion is hard to recommend across the board because there are big pros and big cons. In the latter column: I don't see Notion's vision of a single, integrated app reflected in this product. Even its companion apps (Calendar and Mail) are very poorly integrated. The main complaint I see from other people online is that Notion can come with a huge cost in setup time and learning curve, and I agree that this is a risk. Notion gives you an empty workspace, which is its biggest pro and biggest con, depending on your use case. If you want a team project management app that is ready to go, Monday or ClickUp might be better. And the lack of an offline mode is almost unforgivable. Project and task clarity, fast access to information.

title: "A Game-Changer for Modern HR Teams"
description: I use Notion every day in my HR role, and it’s truly transformed how I organize, document, and collaborate. The flexibility of the platform makes it easy to create living documents, workflows, and knowledge bases that my team can actually use—not just reference once and forget.  The real standout recently has been Notion’s AI features. I rely on it for summarizing lengthy policy drafts, rewriting content in a more human tone, and even generating first drafts of job descriptions or onboarding plans. It’s like having an extra teammate who’s always ready to help me think and write faster. Permissions can be a bit tricky, especially when you're trying to share a single page without giving access to the full workspace or when collaborating across teams with different levels of visibility. I’ve also noticed performance can lag a bit in large, complex workspaces or when there are lots of embedded databases on a single page. And while the AI is great for drafting and summarizing, it’s still learning—sometimes the rewrites feel too generic or miss the tone I’m going for. It’s also helping solve the “blank page” problem with AI. Whether I’m drafting a new policy, writing a performance improvement plan, or rewording a handbook section, Notion AI helps me move from idea to first draft faster. That means I spend more time thinking strategically and less time formatting or copy-pasting between tools.

title: "Scalable Flexibility"
description: As a user of Notion in a personal capacity since 2018, and in a professional one, since 2022, I have seen drastic growth, in what features are available. I love how it can be as simple or as complex as you want. Often, the way I view a project changes, and being able to rework my database without losing content or time is a life saver. I use Notion several times a day to keep every aspect of my life organized. If I was able to pick what projects get implemented next, I would choose: more functions for the databases, offline mode (but that's already in the works), and conservation of data when exporting. You can print database pages, but as a math nerd I would want more tools to play around with, and when I'm done, I want the printouts to look a bit better. I work for a small laboratory, where we all "wear different hats"  and have different roles. Since I have to be familiar with thousands of different processes (that may only come up once every 2+ years), it is easy to forget how I did things last time. With Notion, I can search for keywords and receive my answer, an informative summary, and a link to all relevant pages, in seconds. I went from not recording anything to using post-it notes, to having a supercharged personal assistant. This also have made it much easier for me to share methods with my colleagues. Tasks get done quickly and correctly, the first time.

title: "Effortless and smart. Definitely recommended"
description: Notion makes work feel lighter. It’s simple to use, flexible enough for anything from docs to team wikis, and honestly a no-brainer for keeping things organized at work. The built-in AI assistant has been a game changer super helpful without needing to switch tools or worry about sensitive company info getting out. It’s all right there, safe and seamless. Love how much smoother it’s made our workflow. There was a bit of a learning curve at the beginning, it took some time to really get the hang of how Notion works. The cursor can also feel a bit glitchy at times, especially when it randomly selects the whole page instead of just a block. Also, there are so many cool Notion hacks out there, but they’re not easy to discover unless you go digging. Would love to see more of those surfaced in-app or through official tips. Centralized documentation with high level safety and confidentiality.

title: "I've built my life on notion, so easy to get organized and knowledge share both at work and home!"
description: Notion is extremely easy to pick up and use day to day. While I mostly use it as a general documents/knowledge/notepad, it's easy to organize everything in concise home-pages that are personalized to what I do every day. I have enjoyed the new AI capabilities as well and have used that quite a bit as I've gotten up to speed at a new employer who uses Notion as our internal knowledge base. AI makes it easy to search using normal language and get answers based on the pages within my Notion account. Will definitely continue recommending and leveraging Notion! Would be nice to get a Notion Calendar App for Ipad, but other than that, it's great! I primarily use notion for customer notes, opportunity management (in addition to salesforce), and as an internal knowledge base for work. I also use Notion at home as a one-stop shop for information about contractors, big projects we're taking on, tracking categorized notes (kids, food, recipes, garden, etc.), and for managing travel bookings in a consolidated place.

title: "So close, but also so far."
description: I appreciate that Notion is trying to be a "one-stop shop" so that teams don't have to context/tool switch as often throughout the day. The Notion AI feature has greatly reduced time to find information across the org. I appreciate how customizable and flexible the platform is and that it can be used in a variety of use cases. Customer support is solid for small bugs, as they're generally quick to respond.  My customer support rep has been helpful and was able to connect me to the Product team for a feedback session. It seems like there are a lot of ideas and good directions, but things never quite get to 100% complete, which means, as customers, we continually have to find "workaround" solutions.  If there's a Notion update that then allows for some of the workarounds to be deprecated, there isn't usually a great way to transition off one solution to the next without massive manual work, which can be frustrating.  Our customer rep had some good recommendations for us on some of our setup, but again, they require massive amounts of manual work for what is realistically a small change in the grand scheme. The suggestion was for us to hire an external consultant to do the work for us, which was frankly a little frustrating. It shouldn't be so difficult to shift approaches, in a tool that was meant to be flexible, that it requires hiring a consultant.  The project management features, in particular, feel pretty half-baked still. Automations, while getting better, still require a lot of Notion-specific syntax experience to work correctly. Often the RIO of investing time to make the automation work ultimately doesn't save enough time to justify not just doing it manually. Database templates still don't inherently work correctly for project databases and haven't for at least 2 years. The fact that the task database creates an empty page for every task and subtask is painful and can cause loading issues as databases get larger.  A lot of Notion AI features have been teased for a while without any real updates (i.e, I first heard about the Salesforce and Zendesk integrations about a year ago, they just got announced as "coming soon", but my rep still can't give me even a quarter ETA to expect the release).  Page analytics rolled out and never went anywhere else despite having plenty of improvement options. Responses for anything that have to be taken to the Eng team seem to end up in a black hole and never get resolved or updated. Being able to search in one place across all of our tools is beneficial. Having a centralized place to put our knowledge for each functional team is useful. It's currently solving our need for a project management solution, but wouldn't necessarily recommend that to others.
reviewerTitle: Manager Program and Project Management Team

title: "Love Notion.. but.."
description: - Really amazing UX and easy to work with it. Databases are super powerful and I love how it integrates in so many workflows. Templates is something I use as well. Like ability to mention people and pages. Ability to embed various other things docs/links/loom videos/youtube videos/github PRs is great! I just love that. For project management and working with various TODOs is great too. I love the new AI features: specially Search with AI, AI editor to rewrite my sentences with clarity. I also use it to extend and brainstorm ideas by providing current context and ask it to generate further. Working with tables. If there are lot of columns in the table, it gets really difficult to bring specific column to view. Also if someone has commented on something, I usually go from highlight in the column to comment. It is not trivial to understand where the comment is . It is sometimes very not-user-friendly.  I also find it difficult at times to add a new block below table. Have to struggle with context menu. Not always but often.  I also find sometimes notion search is slow in a really large org, AI search helps. I also ran into issues of importing a large CSV to a notion table or database, and it didn't work at all. - Notion allows me to write documents and allow me to refine my writing through AI writing assistant. It also helps me change my tone based on the audience I am addressing - It allows me to collaborate with many people in the team and tables as well as databases allow project management and tasks really good. - I work in a large org and I need to find lot of things from simple text to even errors in code. The AI search is great for that.

title: "Notion makes threat intelligence program set-up easy."
description: I use Notion everyday from work to personal, and if there is ever an issue Notion is quick to help.  I love how simple Notion makes organizing team development. The ability to create separate workspaces for different teams is a huge plus. I also enjoy building databases and templates to streamline workflows. It’s easy to set up a threat intelligence team and create an internal sharing platform for an organization, giving guests access only to what they need, while keeping sensitive areas private. Some features I wish Notion offered: More robust form capabilities. For instance, being able to share a form with a guest that has a connected database would be extremely useful, especially for collecting IOCs or external inputs securely.  Stronger integrations with industry tools. Integrations with platforms like VirusTotal, Dehashed, OSINT Industries, and IBM X-Force Exchange would greatly enhance Notion’s utility for cybersecurity teams.  Cross-workspace database connectivity. If I create ticket trackers in separate guest workspaces, I’d like the option to centralize them into a single master database. Right now, there’s no native way to consolidate or let guests input tickets while viewing only their team’s submissions.  Improved Google Docs export. A smoother, more accurate export to Google Docs would be helpful for sharing reports and write-ups (same for PDF export, you never know where the page break will be).  More features for database analytics and visualization tools. Currently that area feels restrictive.  Native link analysis and graphing. A built-in feature similar to draw.io or Visio would be a game-changer for visualizing threat actor relationships and infrastructure mapping. Ideally, users could generate link analysis charts directly from a database. For example: * Set a header row to define node attributes (e.g., name, type, tags). * Define relationships using a dedicated column where users specify the related row and the type of relationship. * Allow right-click or hover to expand a node and view additional context or metadata. This would enable powerful visual mapping without leaving the Notion workspace—perfect for intelligence workflows, incident investigations, or entity mapping. Notion solves the challenge of organizing team development and intelligence operations in one unified platform. It allows me to create dedicated workspaces for different teams, set up threat intelligence programs, and manage collaboration without needing multiple tools. Databases and templates help streamline repetitive tasks, and the ability to grant selective access means guests can view only what they need—protecting sensitive data while still enabling information sharing. This flexibility lets me build internal platforms for intelligence sharing, ticket tracking, and research collection efficiently and securely.

title: "Makes My Life SO MUCH EASIER"
description: I live in Notion every single day!  Notion AI makes my life so much easier.  I write product documentation for our internal teams - both technical and non-technical users.  I use the Notion AI to help me write that documentation by creating the draft document which I just have to review and polish which is such a leg up from starting every document from scratch.  I also really love the flexibility of Notion.  I have come to use Notion for everything and so far it has been able to meet all of those needs. Notion doesn't seem to play well with Google Meet from a memory perspective.  We use Google Meet frequently for internal meetings.  Any time that I try to change views in Notion while I'm in Google meeting, whether I'm sharing my screen or not, I will frequently lock up my computer.  The Google meet with continue with audio only but the video is unresponsive until I can restart the browser. Notion is our company's centralized documentation repository.  The ability to search the Notion database and to use AI search has been extremely valuable for users who are unfamiliar with other department pages and don't know where to look to find information.  We are also using Notion for collaborative documentation creation and go to market tracking

title: "Notion continues to grow, but is still a core product"
description: The whole idea behind Notion is the relational databases. Once you can tap into that, it's a real superpower towards building a second brain. But even if you just need to jot down some notes, it's great, too. If you use OneNote, or EverNote, or things like that, this completely replaces it much more successfully. Now, with the introduction of AI, it can actually help you along with that journey. I manage my personal side-business with it, as well as my personal life, and I use Notion daily for the past 3 years. It has become an integral part of my life. I find that I am more productive when I use it, and less productive when not. As Notion continues to expand, there is concern from a core network of users that they might be adding new features at the peril of old features. Recently, they've added Calendar and Email apps. As well as the huge AI features. I think Notion is still Notion, but should be something to watch for in the future. A complete tracking database for all of my "stuff." It also allows relational linking and ease of use to access that stuff. I am still learning how to integrate AI fully, but have used it to help with language and messaging from time to time.

title: "My Daily Hub for Getting Things Done"
description: What I like best about Notion is how flexible it is. I can build exactly what I need without it feeling complicated. One day I’m tracking tasks in a simple list, and the next I’m using a board to manage a whole project. It adjusts to how my brain works, not the other way around. I also love that everything stays in one clean space—notes, goals, and plans—so I don’t waste time jumping between different apps. It just helps me stay organized and calm, even on busy days. What I dislike about Notion is that it can feel a little slow sometimes, especially when I have a lot of pages or big databases open. It takes a second to load and that small delay can add up when I’m in the middle of a busy work session. Also, because it’s so flexible, it’s easy to go down a rabbit hole tweaking layouts instead of just getting things done. I had to learn to keep it simple or I’d spend more time building my workspace than actually using it. Notion is solving my biggest problem of having everything scattered across notebooks, apps, and random sticky notes. Now I have one place where I can plan, track, and review all my work without jumping around. It helps me stay focused on what matters most each day. I can see all my projects, deadlines, and ideas at a glance, which keeps me from feeling overwhelmed. Since using it, I spend less time trying to remember where things are and more time actually making progress. It’s helped me work smarter and feel more in control.

title: "Notion has been a gamechanger."
description: I love the way it pushes me to think in a more structured way. The AI assistant acts as a great thought partner so my workflow has been much more focused toward the tasks. I also love the database integrations. It's easy to access info between documents, projects, databases, and the calendar. Notion can be a bit tedious for users who don't have the patience to code. Even with the templates that other Notion users make available, it takes some time and critical thinking to customize the templates to your particular needs/goals. It gets a bit overwhelming to figure out – sometimes I take some days away from a page/template/database to give myself a brainbreak. I suppose its best quality is also its worst quality. Notion solves the problem of unclearly communicated expectations with my team. The AI Writing Assistant does an outstanding job of rewriting and summarizing meeting notes and action items. It also mind-maps very well so the workflow/timeline of our projects is clearly represented for the whole team. There are fewer questions about projects because there is greater clarity about what we're working toward and the steps necessary to get there.

title: "A Game-Changer for Organizing, Automating, and Scaling My Business"
description: Notion is the brain of my business. From centralized knowledge management to real-time team collaboration, it helps streamline everything—from client onboarding to project execution. The AI Writing Assistant is a massive time-saver for documentation, SOPs, and creative brainstorming. Enterprise Search lets me find exactly what I need across dozens of workspaces in seconds. The only downside is performance lag with very large databases and slow syncing across devices when managing high-volume automation logs. I’d also like to see deeper native integrations with platforms like Go High Level and MySQL to reduce dependence on third-party connectors.  Are you a guest user or a business user of Notion? Notion acts as the command center for my business. It’s helped eliminate scattered tools by combining wikis, SOPs, project tracking, and CRM data into one customizable space. I’ve built entire dashboards to manage client work, track SEO, store internal systems, and coordinate team sprints. It saves time, reduces back-and-forth, and enables my small team to punch above our weight.

title: "It's worth the learning curve; AI top notch!"
description: Notion allows me and my team to organize all of our thoughts, trade ideas, and build out plans for content planning. I love that you can nest pages within each other. The toggles and forms of organizing allow for easy ways to get a ton of information on a page and condense it. The AI is the best part. It's expensive, but worth the money because you can search through your notion docs and ask it to read the page and generate more content or plans. It's all we use to organize documents! It was a steep learning curve because it's overwhelming. There's so much you can do with notion but it's hard to know where to begin. The training videos are helpful and many of the templates are too, but they can also be intense. Take time to get to know the software. It holds all of our content and content planning. We're the in-house marketing team at a non-profit. I love that it cross-searches information across our notion docs. So the AI is super smart and allows me to reference other docs within the database.

title: "Notion AI Meeting Notes are a Game Changer!"
description: I've recently started using Notion's AI meeting notes to take notes for me while I'm in business meetings.  They are a total game changer as they allow me to focus on the discussion without being distracted with writing notes about what is going on or worse, trying to remember after the meeting what happened.  Notion's AI Meeting notes will quickly give me high level info of what happened in my meeting and I have the ability to edit if anything is incorrect - like 'Jon' is spelled 'John' (that is a recent example).  Once you try them, you will not be able to attend a meeting without them any longer! Notion's learning curve is bit steep, but once you get the hang of how the app works then it's an essential tool to use on a daily basis. Notion is solving note taking during meetings, document organization, and searching - I use Notion daily now.  My team and I are building a fully searchable repository of technical documents with Notion.  This is helping us resolve software issues and search for common issues that have surfaced previously.

title: "Flexible, Customizable, and Researcher-Friendly: A Powerful e-Lab Notebook with Room to Grow"
description: Notion has become the central hub for managing my research workflow. As an electronic lab notebook (e-LN), it’s highly adaptable—I use linked databases to track experiments, literature reviews, project milestones, and protocols, all in one place. The ability to create custom views (calendar, timeline, Kanban) and tag entries by type or status allows me to visualize my work dynamically. It’s especially powerful when combined with versioned file storage, cross-platform access, and the integration of structured templates. Unlike rigid ELN platforms, Notion gives me the flexibility to build a system that aligns exactly with how I think and work. Notion’s performance degrades when handling very large pages or embedded content-heavy databases. There’s also limited offline functionality, which can be disruptive in environments with unstable internet. While Notion excels at flexibility, it lacks native scientific features like experiment timers, chemical structure rendering, or protocol version control, which more specialized ELN platforms offer. Export options are also limited when it comes to generating clean, formatted lab reports or PDFs for compliance or archiving. Notion solves the fragmentation problem in academic and lab work. Before, I relied on separate tools for note-taking, task tracking, protocol management, and project planning. Now, everything lives in one unified system. I’ve built a modular, searchable electronic lab notebook that allows me to track experiments by date, tag literature by topic, log progress across multiple projects, and centralize protocols—all cross-linked and version-controlled. This has improved my ability to plan experiments, retrieve information quickly, and maintain reproducibility and traceability in my research. It’s also significantly reduced administrative overhead and cognitive load.

title: "My go-to Software EVERY time!"
description: I love the ability to customize my workspaces (I call them Dashboards) for the way I think and work. It's easy to integrate other products I use into my dashboards so I can keep all of my "digital knowledge" in one location. I use Notion every day, and appreciate how easy it was to get started using it in the beginning. I've interacted with their customer support and they've been extremely responsive every time. I also appreciate how the company responds to feature requests and implements them quickly. The AI writing assistant, search, and other AI features have been great. I don't see any downsides to using it, I would just like it if they would add handwriting/drawing with a stylus capabilities to the software. Getting better organized so I can be more productive in my consulting business. It also helps me organize my knowledge management across all of my digital devices.
reviewerTitle: Eye Care Practice Consultant and Optometrist

title: "The only tool that finally organized my brain"
description: Notion is the only tool that has actually earned its place as my second brain. I bought Thomas Frank’s Ultimate Brain template, and now everything—literally everything—has a home. Web clips. Projects. Notes. Half-formed ideas. Stuff I used to scatter across Google Drive, Apple Notes, and a dozen apps now lives in one powerful hub. It’s wildly flexible, but also structured enough to keep me focused. And with Notion AI, building complex databases is shockingly simple. I created a multi-layer referral partner tracking system using Notion AI and ChatGPT faster than any spreadsheet or PM tool I’ve ever used. You can build anything in here—from a basic to-do list to an entire operational ecosystem. It’s like LEGO for your business brain. As much as I want Notion to be the only tool I use, it doesn’t quite get there. It’s not intuitive for team collaboration the way ClickUp is. Yes, you can collaborate in Notion, but it’s not built for that out of the box: you have to engineer it. So I still lean on ClickUp for shared project workflows. Also, Notion’s databases, while powerful, aren’t as formula-friendly as Google Sheets. If you want to do calculations, conditional logic, or advanced filtering, it feels clunky or flat-out missing. title: "Review: Notion with AI – A Game Changer for Productivity"
description: I’ve been using Notion for a while now, and the addition of the AI feature has genuinely transformed how I work. It’s like having an extra brain on hand — whether I’m looking for something in my own documents, searching across the web, or even digging through public pages, it helps me find what I need quickly and effortlessly. That kind of intuitive access has saved me hours.  What I especially appreciate is how seamlessly it integrates with my workflow. The AI doesn’t just answer questions — it surfaces content, links ideas, and makes navigating my workspace incredibly smooth. That said, there is a bit of a learning curve when it comes to formatting. The AI sometimes needs very explicit instructions to make layout or design changes, and it can miss the mark if I’m not crystal clear. Overall, Notion continues to be a powerful, flexible tool, and the AI makes it even more capable — especially when you need speed, clarity, and creative support all in one place. Notion solves the problem of having information scattered across multiple tools. Instead of juggling between docs, task managers, note-taking apps, and wikis, I can keep everything in one place — neatly organised and easily searchable. title: "Notion is flexible easy to understand and has a lot of room to grow in"
description: I like that notion is easy to understand and flexible for any situation it can go from a simple task list to a very complex multi database power house. title: "The best tool for a university student"

title: "Notion does what all my other AI systems wont"
description: I absolutely love that my AI can integrate and research and review all of my databases and workspace information, this is invaluable when I am quickly  searching for info inside of a specific service we offer, and it can even read the contents of my documents and extract the specific phrase i am trying to clarify, like SOPs for my high net worth client consultancies. title: "My Take on Notion AI"

title: "A Clean & flexible platform for organizing your work"
description: Notion replaces a lot of the Google suite tools, and because it's not made by Google, it's visually pleasant and user-friendly easy to to work with. It has advanced features but lightweight enough none of these are a barrier to using it immediately.  Notion is also good for collaboration -- each document has easy to understand, fine-grained permissions and it's easy to comment, link to or mention internal and external documents. Unfortunately, Notion has reached the point where it suffers from feature bloat. There are probably too many features at this point, and I'd rather they prune some of the ones that are distracting, and focus on performance / UX clarity.  The NotionAI pop up is pretty annoying, it's easy to trigger accidentally, and I've never used it because I can't think of any use case in which it would be helpful.  If I need boilerplate copy I go to ChatGPT directly. The AI  search is vaguely useful but I'd feel more confident in the results if I could get links to source documents. The task I have the most trouble with is using advanced database features, perhaps if Notion AI could suggest alternate ways to organize info (but only if its unobtrusive / happens when I ask -- we don't want a "Clippy" scenario).  For users who belong to multiple Notion workspaces, the dropdown toggle is a bit annoying. I wish I could have a homepage that let me pull from different workspaces, or keep global favorites in the sidebar (pulling from any workspace I belong to). I also wish it was easier to see when I have notifications in workspace A when I primarily spend time in workspace B. I'm a software engineer at a medium sized consultancy. Notion helps me collaboration with coworkers and external stakeholders , manage non-technical work (especially QA and Support tickets, surveys, etch), take notes at meetings, draft routine communications (although I wish the formatting was more consistent when I paste them into Gmail) and read company manuals.

title: "Notion Replaces Sharepoint, Google Drive, Etc."
description: I love Notion's versatility and customization. It's not just a note-taking app—it's a project management tool, a personal wiki, a database, and so much more. Notion solves the problem of fragmented information by centralizing notes, project management, and documentation in one intuitive workspace. title: "Notion AI & creating documentation"
description: I love Notion AI's ability to pull comprehensive, context-aware answers from a variety of integrated tools—including Notion, Slack, and Google drive. This integration streamlines information retrieval by surfacing insights from across our knowledge base, project boards, and team conversations. title: "Goodproduct want to be more accessible"
description: 🔮 The AI Assistant Notion AI is incredibly helpful. It assists with summarizing content, generating outlines, and brainstorming ideas. As someone who manages many projects, this feature helps me move faster and think more clearly. It's one of the best parts of the Notion experience, and I use it often. ♿ Accessibility for Blind Users This is where Notion falls short. As a blind user who relies on screen readers, I find the interface challenging to navigate. The block-based structure, while powerful visually, doesn't always translate well into screen reader-friendly interactions. Key problems include: • Unlabeled or confusing elements • Difficult keyboard navigation • Inconsistent focus and reading order Accessibility improvements would not only make Notion more inclusive but also empower more blind professionals to adopt it into their workflows. Notion gives me one place to draft, update, and organize specifications for the tools and products I work on. I can create structured documents with headings, tables, and toggles, making it easier to break down technical ideas or feature requirements. Its flexibility helps me keep everything connected—linking specs to tasks, timelines, or databases without juggling separate apps.

title: "Notion is easy and powerful"
description: How easy it is to use. I was using Confluence at my last job, which is powerful but not simple. The best part about Notion is how easy it is to use. title: "How Notion Helps Me Enhance My Productivity"

One thing I dislike about Notion is its limited backlinking and knowledge visualization features. This makes it harder to explore relationships between notes or build a networked thinking system for research and creative projects. Additionally, Notion can feel sluggish with large databases or complex pages, and its offline functionality is limited, which can be frustrating when I need to work without a stable internet connection. Notion solves the problem of scattered information by combining note-taking, task management, databases, and collaboration tools into one unified workspace. This centralization helps me stay focused and reduces the time I spend switching between tools. Notion’s flexibility also lets me build custom workflows that match the way I think—whether it’s tracking research, planning a project timeline, or creating a content calendar. As a result, I feel more in control of my work and better able to manage both daily tasks and long-term goals.
